list.item: The common good of society depends upon the search for truth and its free exposition. Academic freedom in both teaching and research is essential to these purposes.
Members are entitled to the freedom to carry out research and to publish the results, to the freedom to teach and discuss their subjects, and to the freedom from institutional censorship.
Academic freedom carries with it the duty to use that freedom in a responsible way.

The main objectives of this Collective Agreeement are the specification of principles and procedures that reflect procedural fairness for academic personnel decisions, the peaceful settlement of all disputes, misunderstandings and grievances, and the promotion of harmonious relations between the Board and the Association.

The Board and the Association acknowledge
their joint responsibility for the reasonable and just execution of the terms of the Collective Agreement; and
subject to the provisions of the Post-Secondary Learning Act, Labour Relations Code, and all applicable provincial and federal statutes, this Collective Agreement is binding on the Association, the Academic Staff, and the Board.
Toward that end, any invocation of Article 22regarding a Collective Agreement procedure in progress shall stay the procedure pending a resolution of the interpretation or grievance.
Any deadlines mentioned in this agreement may be varied by written mutual consent prior to the deadline by the Board and the Association.
“Academic Assistant” shall mean a member of the academic staff holding an appointment with the rank of Academic Assistant III, Academic Assistant II, or Academic Assistant I.

“Academic Career” shall mean a period of
thirty-five (35) cumulative years for Members who hold the rank of Professor or Professional Librarian IV; or
twenty-five (25) cumulative years for Members who hold the rank of Associate Professor or Professional Librarian III; or
ten (10) years for Members who hold the rank of Assistant Professor or Professional Librarian II.
The maximum number of academic career years as defined here does not preclude an individual from spending more or fewer years as a Faculty Member/Professional Librarian.

“Agreement” or "Collective Agreement" shall mean the Collective Agreement, including schedules thereto. The edition of the Collective Agreement in effect is the one most recently ratified by the Board and the Association, including schedules thereto and any interpretations pursuant to Article 22.
“Association” shall mean The University of Lethbridge Faculty Association.

"Bargaining Year" shall mean a period between July 1 and June 30 in which bargaining between the Association and the University is active or expected or required to commence in accordance with Article 3or applicable legislation.
“Board” shall mean the Board of Governors of The University of Lethbridge.
“Dean” shall mean the Dean of a Faculty or a person authorized to act in that capacity.

“Dean/University Librarian” shall mean Dean if affecting the Members in a Faculty or University Librarian if affecting Professional Librarians, or Dean of the Faculty of Education if affecting the Members in the Curriculum Laboratory.
“Department” shall mean an academic unit established by the Board under that designation.
“Department Chair” shall mean a person authorized to act in that capacity.
“Faculty” shall mean an academic unit established by the Board under that designation.
“Faculty Member” shall mean a member of the academic staff with the rank of Professor, Associate Professor, or Assistant Professor.

"Handbook," when used of the current agreement, is a synonym for Collective Agreement. Historically, the term was used to refer to agreements covering different segments of the Academic Staff Bargaining unit. This use is retained in schedules and attachments.
“Instructor” shall mean an employee of the academic staff holding an appointment with the rank of Instructor III, Instructor II, or Instructor I.

"Intellectual property" shall mean any result of intellectual or artistic activity that is created by a Member and that can be owned by a person. Intellectual property includes, but is not limited to inventions, publications, computer software, works of visual art and music, industrial and artistic designs, plant cultivars, integrated circuit topography as well as all other creations that can be protected under patent, copyright, trademark or similar laws.
“Member” shall mean an employee of the Board who is a member of the Academic Staff as defined in Article 4.03.
"Non-bargaining year" shall mean a period between July 1 and June 30 in which collective bargaining between the University and the Association does not and is not expected to occur.
“Parties” shall mean the Board and the Association.

“Part Time” shall mean a Member who has been assigned duties but is not a Sessional Lecturer, a Member on Reduced Load Status (Article 33), nor a Member who has been assigned duties on a full load basis.
“Personal file” shall mean the file maintained by the Dean/University Librarian pertaining to a Member and which contains materials subject to Article 9 of this Collective Agreement.
“President” shall mean the President of the University, or a person authorized to act in that capacity.

“Professional Librarian” shall mean a member of the academic staff holding an appointment in the University Library or in the Curriculum Laboratory of the Faculty of Education with the rank of Professional Librarian IV, Professional Librarian III, or Professional Librarian II and holding an academic degree and a degree in librarianship from an accredited library school or its equivalent.

“Senior Academic Administrator(s)” shall include the following officials or persons authorized to act in these capacities
The President,
The Vice President and Association Vice President (Academic),
The Vice President and Associate Vice President (Research),
The Vice President and Association Vice President (Finance and Administration)
Deans and Associate Deans,
The University Librarian and Associate University Librarian(s)

“Sessional Lecturer” shall mean a member of the Academic Staff appointed by the Dean of a Faculty or School at the rank of Sessional Lecturer IV, Sessional Lecturer III, Sessional Lecturer II, or Sessional Lecturer I. to teach no more than one semester course in a designated semester. Normally, the Sessional Lecturer has full responsibility for the course, but on occasion a Sessional Lecturer will be a member appointed at a partial stipend to teach a defined portion of a course with corresponding teaching responsibilities.
“University” shall mean The University of Lethbridge.
“University Librarian” shall mean the University Librarian of the University or a person authorized to act in that capacity.
“Vice-President (Academic)” shall mean the Provost and Vice-President (Academic) of the University, or a person authorized to act in that capacity.

item.hi: Duration and Continuance of the Agreement

list.item: This Collective Agreement shall be the only Collective Agreement in effect and shall continue in force, together with any amendments agreed upon under Article 3.02, following its expiry during any period of negotiation until a new agreement is ratified. Article 3.03 ("Strikes and Lockouts") shall not be in effect after the expiration of the agreement, subject to applicable legislation.

The parties to this agreement may occasionally make limited modification and specify their agreement by signing a Memorandum of Agreement/Understanding through the Grievance and Interpretation Processes in Article 22.

Otherwise, negotiations for renewal of this Collective Agreement shall take place in accordance with the regulations of the Post-Secondary Learning Act and Alberta Labour Relations Code and any applicable legislation.
To consider the proposed amendments, each party shall designate a negotiating committee of three persons. The two committees shall meet to negotiate the proposed amendments.

If the parties agree upon an amendment of this Collective Agreement, the agreement shall include a specification of the date upon which the amendment takes effect, and the amendment shall thereafter become part of this Collective Agreement.

In the event that any provision of this Collective Agreement is found to be illegal or unenforceable by a court or tribunal of competent jurisdiction, then such provision shall be severed from the Collective Agreement as having no force or effect; but the remainder of the Collective Agreement shall continue in full force and effect. In the event any such decision of a court or tribunal of competent jurisdiction is appealed, the operation of the provision in question shall be suspended pending the outcome of such appeal.

The Faculty Association agrees that it shall not engage in or participate in any strike or picketing during the currency of this agreement. The University agrees that it shall not lock out any academic staff members during the currency of this agreement.

Any academic staff member who refuses to cross a picket line established by another certified bargaining agent in consequence of job action shall not be in breach of this Agreement, and shall not be subject to disciplinary action nor loss of pay providing the member performs his or her normal duties.
In the event of a strike or lockout involving other bargaining units at the University, academic staff members shall not be required to perform the work of those employees during job action.
Except as provided in Articles 4.02 ("Senior Academic Administrators"), the provisions of this Collective Agreement shall apply to all Members of the Academic Staff.
Subject to Article 1 ("Purpose and Objectives") Senior Academic Administrators shall execute the terms of this Collective Agreement.
When Senior Academic Administrators are acting as members of the academic staff, all terms of the Collective Agreement shall apply to them except Articles 32, 14.03.2, and SchedulesA, Band F.

Where the application of an Article to a Senior Academic Administrator would require action by that administrator constituting or leading to a conflict of interest, the person who supervises that administrator shall act in his/her stead. Where the person in a conflict of interest is the President, the Vice-President (Academic) shall act instead.
When Senior Academic Administrators who hold concurrent academic rank have ceased to hold a senior administrative appointment, all terms of the Collective Agreement shall apply to them.

An employee shall be designated as a member of the academic staff provided that his/her regular duties to be assigned pursuant to Article 13consist of some combination of scholarly research, professional librarianship, academic administration, or the teaching one or more full credit course(s) per year.

Members of the academic staff may have sessional contracts, term positions, tenured or continuing positions, or reduced load positions (see Article 33); they may also be members of the administrative staff.

A retired Member who has been offered an academic appointment at the University shall be a member of the academic staff provided that his/her duties are consistent with the requirements identified in Article 4.03.1.

Those members of the academic staff who are also Senior Academic Administrators as specified in Article 2.24shall be deemed inactive members of ULFA. Inactive members of the Association do not participate in the activities of the Association wherever such participation would be a conflict of interest, nor do they pay dues.

Those members of the academic staff who are nominated by GFC and elected by the academic staff to serve as members of the Board of Governors and those nominated by the Association to serve on the Board of Governors shall be deemed to be inactive members of the Association for the term specified in the Order in Council for their appointment to the Board or as long as such individuals serve on the Board. These Members shall also be excluded from serving on all personnel committees under Article 17during the time they serve on the Board.

In each contract year, the Board shall make available to the Association for each inactive Member a sum equal to the current Association dues and assessments paid by active members as in Article 5.04. Inactive Members of the Association are excluded from Association benefits only as stated in Article 4.02.

The Board contribution for inactive Members, as provided in Article 4.04, shall be paid in monthly instalments, based on the academic portion of their salaries, and in a manner similar to and with information as provided in Article 5.04for Members.
The Board recognizes the Association as the exclusive bargaining agent for all Members, except as provided in Article 4.02.
Both the Board and the Association undertake to protect the security and privacy of these documents.
In no case may documents be used for purposes other than those detailed in this collective agreement.
Association Staff are not employees of the University, and will not participate in the benefits or the personnel policies of the University employees.
Electronic correspondence or communication carried on among Members of the Association, its Staff, office, or officers, shall be the property of the Members or the Association.
Every Member shall have the right to join the Association and as a member of the Association to participate in its activities.

The University shall not interfere with Members of the Association attending Association meetings or attending to Association business providing such participation or attendance does not interfere unreasonably with the performance of the Member's teaching or administrative duties under this Agreement.
A Member's service to the Faculty Association shall be considered service to the University in evaluation of performance under Article 12.02.3 (Service to the University and Society).

The University recognizes that Members, subject to their obligations under this Agreement, have the right to attend open meetings of the Board, and to attend any open meetings of the committees of these bodies.

The Association has the right at any time to call upon the assistance of duly authorized representatives of the Canadian Association of University Teachers (CAUT) and the Confederation of Alberta Faculty Associations (CAFA). Such duly authorized representatives shall have access to the University premises to consult with Association officials and Members.
At the commencement of the Agreement, the Association shall advise the University in writing of the amount of its regular dues and assessments.

Thereafter the Association shall advise the University in writing of any change in the amount of regular dues or assessments; such notice to be given at least twenty (20) days prior to the effective date of such change.

The Board shall by the 15th day of each month remit to the Association:
the dues deducted from each Member for the previous month as assessed by the Association; and
a written statement of the name of the employee for whom the deduction was made and of the amount of the employee's wages of each deduction.

The Board shall inform the Association of the name of and the deductions made for each Member, and may provide CAUT or CAFA with the following information:
Academic Rank
Number of Members in each Academic Rank
Total Amount Being Remitted for that Academic Rank.

item.hi: Course Release Time Provided by the Board

list.item:
The Association shall be entitled to free members of its Executive or Committee from teaching duties on the following basis at no cost to the Association:
Non-Bargaining Year (as defined in 2.17)
Five (5) single 3-credit courses, or proportionate equivalent in courses and other duties in the case of Instructors/Academic Assistants and Professional Librarians.
Bargaining Year (as defined in 2.05):
Two (2) additional single 3-credit courses for a total of seven (7), or proportionate equivalent in courses and other duties in the case of Instructors/Academic Assistants and Professional Librarians.
Release time is calculated on the basis of an twelve month period from July 1-June 30.

No more than two (2) Members accorded release in any non-bargaining year shall be accorded more than two (2) single course release rates, and only at a rate of one (1) course release rate per regular semester; and

No more than three (3) Members accorded release in any bargaining year shall be accorded more than two (2) single course release rates, and only at a rate of one (1) course release rate per regular semester.

item.hi: Course Release Time Purchased by the Association

list.item: No member shall be accorded more than one (1) single 3-credit course release (or proportionate equivalent for Instructors/Academic Assistants) purchased by the Association under Article 5.06.1.
The cost to the Association for course release purchased under Article 5.06.1shall be an amount equal to the minimum course overload stipend plus 25%.

Unless an alternate arrangement is made, should the Association request that course release rates be accorded at a rate of two (2) course release rates in one (1) regular semester, both releases shall be permitted through the Association remitting to the Board a total amount equal to one (1) third of the minimum salary for an Assistant Professor, as identified in Schedule of this Collective Agreement; and

As soon as possible after the Annual General Meeting, the Association shall inform the President and the relevant supervisors of the individuals who are being recommended for course release rates. The weighting of the criteria for the Member's performance evaluation may be altered by the Dean/University Librarian in consultation with the Member.

Following ratification of a new Collective Agreement, the parties will cooperate in any technical editing of the new Agreement and will jointly prepare the master copy of the draft form. This process shall not delay implementation or signing of the agreement.
The Board agrees to provide on request to each Member a copy of this Agreement within sixty (60) days after the signing of this Agreement or upon appointment in the case of new employees.
The Board agrees to provide to the Association sixty (60) copies for its own use within sixty (60) days after the signing of this Agreement.
The official copy of the Collective Agreement shall be posted on the University's website as soon as it is practicable to do so following the ratification and technical editing of the agreement.
The most recent version of the Collective Agreement shall always be accessible from .
Where appropriate, the website will also provide links to Memoranda of Agreement of general application concerning the Collective Agreement.

Except where otherwise specified in this Agreement, correspondence between the Association and the University arising out of this Agreement or incidental thereto shall pass between the President of the University and the President of the Association, or their designates.

Where written notice is specified in the Agreement, email shall be deemed adequate means for correspondence between the Association and the University for all Articles except Articles 22 (Grievance and Interpretation) and 25 (Discpline).
All communications required by Articles 22 and 25 shall be delivered during business hours in a manner that permits acknowledgement of receipt if requested or if required by this Agreement.
Email delivered outside of business hours shall be deemed to have been delivered at 8:30am on the next business day.

This shall not be construed as to require either party to compile information and statistics in the form requested if such data are not already compiled in the form requested.
The Board shall provide all personal contact information for Members of the Association to the Association in a bargaining year prior to the start of collective bargaining.

Personal information provided by the Board under this Article shall be maintained and used by the Association only for the purposes of operating the Association in accordance with the provisions of the Post Secondary Learning Act, the Alberta Labour Relations Code, the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act, this Collective Agreement and the Association by-laws.

The University shall provide the Association with the following information in October of each year:
Number of Continuing Members and Term Members in their benefit categories, broken down by single or family coverage; this information to be complete as of September 30 and provided to the Association no later than October 31.

The University shall provide the Association with the following information in October and April of each year:
a list of all term and Sessional Lecturer appointments in the last twelve months, with name, Faculty, appointment start date, appointment end date and the reasons for the appointment pursuant to Article 18.02.2.C.
The list will be complete as of September 30 and March 31 and provided no later than October 31 and April 30, respectively.

The President shall make available to the Association upon written request and within a reasonable time, information on Members not provided in Articles 6.03.4 6.03.5, and 6.03.6. This section shall not be construed to require the President to compile information in the form requested if such data are not already compiled in the form requested, or to supply any confidential information.

Either the Association or the University may request a meeting to discuss the information with a view to identifying any anomalies and responding to any concerns about trends in these data. The University undertakes to deal effectively with these anomalies within one calendar year.
The President of the University and the President of the Association shall, by October 15 of each year, agree to a date for a meeting of representatives of the parties.
Each party shall submit to the other not less than five (5) working days before the scheduled date of the meeting a list of particular matters to be discussed.
No more than five (5) representatives from each party shall attend such meetings.
Matters that would normally be dealt with in Article 22shall not be the subject matter of these meetings.
Any task required herein to be performed by the Board may by the Board's delegation be performed by the President.

Any task required herein to be performed by the President may be delegated by the President as he/she sees fit, and the President may prescribe conditions governing the exercise of any delegated task including the power of subdelegation. Any task required herein to be performed by the Vice-President (Academic), a Dean, or the University Librarian may be delegated under the same provisions that apply to the President.

Any task required herein to be performed by the President of the Association may be delegated by him/her as he/she sees fit, and he/she may prescribe conditions governing the exercise of any delegated task including the power of subdelegation.

Where a task required herein is delegated under the provisions of this Article, the force of the performance of that task shall be the same as if performed by the delegator, upon whom the results of the performance shall be binding.
The delegation of a task required herein shall be made known in writing to the Members affected.

The appropriate Dean/University Librarian shall maintain a personal file on each Member for purposes defined by this Collective Agreement. This file contains personal information relating to employment and educational history.
Only materials relating to employment and educational history and which are relevant to purposes of the Collective Agreement shall be entered into the file.

All materials considered by a personnel committee regarding a Member and all materials forming the basis of a disciplinary decision regarding a Member shall have been entered in that Member’s personal file.
A Member's personal file shall include all confidential letters of reference pertaining to that Member.

Unless otherwise designated by the author, all letters containing assessments of a Member's performance shall be deemed confidential. All confidential letters of reference shall be signed and dated by their authors; letters which are not signed and dated shall not enter a Member's personal file.

When the President or Dean/University Librarian requests a confidential letter of reference, he/she shall inform the person requested of the provisions of this Article respecting disclosure of confidential information. Before confidential information is disclosed concerning letters of reference which have not been solicited by the President or Dean/University Librarian, he/she shall inform the author of the provisions of this Article. If the author requests in writing, or if the author does not respond, the unsolicited letter shall be destroyed or returned, whichever is more appropriate. Letters of assessment submitted by a Member for inclusion on his/her personal file shall be dealt with according to the provisions of Article 9.06.

A Member shall, upon written request, be given by the President or Dean/University Librarian the names of authors of the confidential letters of reference in his/her personal file, and/or a fair summary of the contents of those letters, except where fewer than three letters are involved, in which case only the fair summary shall be provided. In this context a fair summary may include quotations from or non-holographic reproduction of the letter itself. The President or Dean/University Librarian shall attempt to preserve confidentiality; however, the requirement of a fair summary shall take precedence over the need for confidentiality where there is a clear conflict between the two principles. The decision of the President or Dean/University Librarian respecting a fair summary and the manner of preservation of confidentiality shall be subject to interpretation in each instance if requested by the Member. The procedure for interpretation shall be as provided in 22, except that the purpose of interpretation shall be to determine whether the nature and extent of confidential information disclosed satisfies the criterion of a fair summary.
Any hearing committee as in Articles 24and 25, or an arbitrator as in Articles 22, shall have the right to decide on questions of fair summary, as provided in Article 9.05.4.

item.hi: Materials Other Than Confidential Letters of Reference

list.item: Materials other than confidential letters of reference may be placed on a Member's personal file only if they are signed and dated by the author and/or institutional source. The Member shall be informed within ten (10) working days that materials have been placed in his/her personal file. Materials not signed and dated shall enter a Member's personal file only with that Member's written authorization in each specific instance. Electronic mail is considered material that is not signed.

item.hi: Materials Obtained Pursuant to the Evaluation of Teaching

list.item: Materials obtained pursuant to a policy on teaching evaluation established according to the provisions of Article 12.03.1 shall be dealt with according to Article 9.05 where individually written assessments of teaching are included, and according to Article 9.06 where other forms of assessment are included, including materials from students. Procedures shall be used that ensure the identity of the student respondent is protected to the maximum extent permitted by law.

item.hi: Inspection and Comment by a Member

list.item: A Member shall have the right, with reasonable notice in writing, to inspect the contents of his/her personal file, except for confidential letters of reference. The Member shall not remove his/her personal file or any part of it. Upon written request, the Member shall be able to obtain copies of the materials which he/she has the right to inspect.

A Member shall have the right to have included in his/her personal file his/her written comments upon the accuracy and/or meaning of any of the contents of that file, and to add materials to the file.

item.hi: Removal of Materials from a File

list.item: The Member, President, or the Dean/University Librarian shall have the right to request in writing the removal of materials included in the Member's personal file on the ground that the materials do not constitute fair and/or relevant comment on the Member's performance.

Records relating to discipline shall be removed from the Member's Personal files after two years. Under Article 9.09.1, Members may request that records relating to a particular set of actions under this Article be removed from their Personal File at an earlier date.

Records relating to major discipline shall be removed from the Member's Personal files after five years. Under Article 9.09.1, Members may request that records relating to a particular set of actions under this Article be removed from their Personal File at an earlier date.

The Member may request material to be removed and destroyed or returned, whichever is more appropriate. This request shall not be unreasonably denied. If the request is denied, the question of fair and/or relevant comment shall be submitted to Article 22grievance procedures in each instance.

Information contained in a personal file shall be made available to persons who require access to perform their duties as specified by an Article of this Collective Agreement. In the conduct of their duties, Senior Academic Administrators shall have access to the files at all times.

A Senior Academic Administrator may seek internal or external advice about items in a Member’s personal file provided that the identity of the Member is not revealed. Otherwise, the information shall be made available only as authorized in writing by the Member, or as required by law.
A Member shall maintain a curriculum vitae in his/her personal file; it shall be updated annually.
Copies of documents in a Member’s personal file may be made only for purposes of the Collective Agreement and such copies must be destroyed when the purpose is met.
Copies of documents made under 9.10.4 must be destroyed when the purpose for which they were copied is met.
Copies of documents made under 9.10.4 have the same status as the original documents and must be handled to the same standard of access and security.

item.hi: Courses Taught in Addition to Assigned Teaching Duties, including Summer Session Courses

list.item: Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.

For course(s) taught over and above a Member’s assigned teaching duties, including those taught during Summer Session, the Member will receive the stipend specified in Schedule A.03. The stipend for a course less than a semester course shall be calculated on a pro rata basis.

In the event that a course under this Article is cancelled thirty (30) working days or fewer from the scheduled commencement of the course, the Member shall receive the partial stipend specified in Schedule A.03.3to recognize the preparation time of the Member.
Copies of contracts for all course overload teaching, studio, ensemble, graduate student, and Post Doctoral Fellow supervision shall be provided to the Association prior to contract start date.
Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.

The Board and Association recognize the need to protect academic freedom. Academic freedom is generally understood as the right to teach, engage in scholarly activity, and perform service without interference and without jeopardizing employment. This freedom is central to the University’s mission and purpose and entails the right to participate in public life, to criticize University or other administrations, to champion unpopular positions, to engage in frank discussion of controversial matters, and to raise questions and challenges which may be viewed as counter to the beliefs of society.

Academic freedom carries with it the duty to use that freedom in a manner consistent with the scholarly obligation to base teaching, scholarly activity and service in an honest and careful search for knowledge.
Members shall respect the academic freedom of others despite differences of opinion.
Academic freedom does not diminish the obligation of Members to fulfill their duties and responsibilities as defined within this Collective Agreement.

The Board and the Association recognize their respective responsibilities to defend academic freedom as specified in this Article. These responsibilities include, but are not limited to, providing legal support to Members in matters that arise from the exercise of academic freedom in accord with Article 11, educating Members on the rights and responsibilities related to academic freedom, and promoting academic freedom.

The Board recognizes a duty to provide, and Members have the right to, a safe workplace free from unfair discrimination, harassment, or abuse of authority and to provide facilities and support services consistent with a Member’s duties and responsibilities as identified in this Collective Agreement.
The Board and the Association shall make efforts to promote and preserve good will among all Members of the University community.
Procedures for the resolution of complaints regarding Article 11.03.1shall be without recrimination or retribution unless the complaints are frivolous or vexatious.

Complaints about a Member pursuant to this Article shall be addressed to the Member, unless the complainant has good reason to fear personal harm or offense. If so, or if the complainant is dissatisfied with the response, the complaint shall be addressed to the Member’s Dean/University Librarian with copies to the Association.

If the Dean/University Librarian cannot hear, receive or act on the complaint(s) in a reasonable time, or should not hear or receive the complaint(s) for reasons of a reasonable apprehension of bias, the complaint(s) shall be referred to that person among the remaining Deans/University Librarian with the most decanal service at the University, and this person shall be deemed to be the appropriate Dean/University Librarian in accordance with Article 9. If necessary, the Office of the Vice-President (Academic) shall direct the complaint to the appropriate Dean/University Librarian.

Complaints that are found to have merit may be entered into the Member's personnel file at the discretion of the Dean and following the procedures in Article 9.06 (Material other than confidential letters of recommendation).

There shall be no unfair discrimination, interference, restriction or coercion practiced with respect to any Member in regard to any terms or conditions of employment by reason of age, race, colour, ethnicity, national origin, philosophical, political, or religious affiliation or belief, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, or physical disability.

There shall be no unfair discrimination practiced with respect to any Member in regard to any terms or conditions of employment by reason of family relationships. However, no Member shall take part in formal discussions or vote with regard to the determination of the terms and conditions of employment of a Member of his/her immediate family.
The Joint Equity Committee (Article 36) shall conduct regular research to determine if unfair or systemic discrimination has occurred.

Except as provided in Article 11.04.1, Members shall have the right to express opinions and to participate by means of their representatives in procedures provided by this Collective Agreement, and in the selection of academic administrators.

As a Union, the Association has the right to be represented and to represent Members at meetings that deal with the interpretation or application of this Agreement, including actual or potential disciplinary action, appeal action for salary, tenure and/or promotion matters.
A Member exerting his/her right under this Article has no obligation to justify the need to be accompanied or the individual who is accompanying them under 11.04.2.C.
A Member may waive one or more of his/her rights under this article, with the exception of the Association's right to be present under Article 11.04.2.B.
A Member shall have the right to make written representation to the Board through the President.
When addressing themselves to the community at large, Members retain the rights and responsibilities which flow from the concept of academic freedom.

Members shall act fairly towards students, other Members, and administrators while acting as teachers, colleagues or administrators. There shall be equitable treatment, no unfair or irrelevant discrimination, objective assessment of performance, due respect for opposing ideas, due acknowledgement of intellectual indebtedness, due respect for privacy and confidentiality, and compliance with this Collective Agreement. Members shall execute their duties in a manner consistent with reasonable, professional expectations, and within the constraints imposed by all legal requirements including this Collective Agreement.

Faculty Members shall have the following responsibilities as scholars:
All scholarly activity conducted by Faculty Members within the University shall have as its primary objectives:
increasing of knowledge and understanding; and
improving their scholarly competence as teachers, including the keeping abreast of recent developments in their disciplines.
Faculty Members are expected to engage in research, scholarly or creative work, to show scholarly integrity therein, and to endeavour to disseminate the results of their scholarship or exhibit the results of their creative work. Gross misconduct in academic research means:
fabrication, falsification, or plagiarism, but not factors intrinsic to the process of academic research, such as honest error, conflicting data or differences in interpretation or assessment of data, or of experimental design;
significant failure to comply with relevant federal or provincial statutes or regulations; or national or international standards for the protection of researchers, human subjects, or the health and safety of the public, or for the welfare of laboratory animals; or significant failure to meet other legal requirements that relate to the conduct of research;
failure to reveal any relevant and substantial conflict of interest to the agencies funding the Member’s University research, to those who commission such research, to an editor or to an agency requesting the Member to undertake reviews of research grant applications or manuscripts for publication, or to an agency requesting the Member to test products for sale or distribution to the public; or
failure to reveal to the University any material financial interest in a company that contracts with the University to supply goods or services directly pertaining to the Member’s University research. Material financial interest includes ownership, substantial stock holding, a directorship, substantial honoraria or consulting fees, but does not include routine stock holding in a large publicly traded company.
Faculty Members shall indicate their affiliation with the University and their reliance on the work and assistance of others, if any, in their published works.

item.hi: Responsibilities in Administrative and Committee Work

list.item: Members are expected to avoid actual or potential conflicts of interest and/or commitment as defined in this Collective Agreement.

No Member shall knowingly participate in any decision making process that directly and preferentially benefits the Member or any individual with whom the Member has an immediate family, financial, personal or business relationship.

An actual or potential conflict of interest arises when a Member is placed in a situation in which his or her personal or financial interests or the interests of his/her immediate family, or persons with whom the Member has a personal or business relationship, conflict or appear to conflict with his or her responsibilities to the University as provided in this Collective Agreement.

An actual or potential conflict of commitment arises when the external activities or commitments of a Member are so substantial such that they interfere with or are so demanding of the Member’s time and attention as to interfere with his or her responsibilities to the University as provided in this Collective Agreement.

The existence of a current or anticipated conflict of interest and/or current or anticipated conflict of commitment does not necessarily preclude the Member’s involvement in the situation where the conflict has arisen, or may arise. There may be situations where a conflict of interest and/or conflict of commitment once declared can be managed so as to enhance rather than undermine the Member’s contributions to the University.

Process for resolving conflicts of interest
If there is reasonable cause to believe that a current or anticipated conflict of interest and/or current or anticipated conflict of commitment may exist, the Member must formally disclose in writing to the Member’s Dean/University Librarian as soon as possible after the Member becomes aware of it.
Following consultation with the Member and other appropriate persons, the Dean/University Librarian will notify the Member whether a current or anticipated conflict of interest and/or conflict of commitment exists and if so, decide how it is to be resolved or managed. The Dean/University Librarian shall state in writing the appropriate manner in which to deal with the current or anticipated conflict of interest and/or conflict of commitment, with copies to the Association.
Consultation and notification shall be conducted in an expeditious manner and approval shall not unreasonably be withheld.
The decision of the Dean/University Librarian shall be subject to appeal to the Vice- President (Academic). The decision of the Vice-President Academic is subject to the conditions of precedural fairness and shall be copied to the Association.

item.hi: Criteria for Extension of Probation, Tenure, Promotion and Salary Increments for Faculty Members

list.item: Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.

The criteria for extension of probation, tenure, promotion and salary increments for Faculty Members are:
Teaching Effectiveness
Effectiveness as a teacher implies a concentrated and successful effort to create the best possible learning situation for students. It involves continuing attention to course work, course design and related activities, and to the supervision of students in alternative modes of learning. It may involve participation in seminars and colloquia, the design of innovative methods of teaching, publication of research on pedagogical practice, or other contributions to the teaching activities of the University and beyond.
Care must be taken to ensure that instruments and evidence presented and used in the evaluation of teaching effectiveness are appropriate and informative. Evidence may include, among other things, self-reflection and evaluation; appraisals by fellow Faculty Members or pedagogical experts; examples of lectures, class material, exams, and assignments; presentations, articles, and practice guides; prizes; and evidence of pedagogical leadership or mentorship at a local, regional, national, or international level.
Student questionnaires are not required for evaluation and no assessment will be based mainly on such appraisals. Consistent with Articles 9.05.2 and 9.07, unsigned appraisals of any kind, including student appraisals of teaching, may not be included in a Member's Personal File or, as a consequence, used as summative criteria under Article 12.
Research and Creative Activity
Where appropriate to the position, efforts shall be made to evaluate the quality and originality of both published and unpublished scholarly work. “Publication” in this context shall be interpreted to include exhibitions and performances, as appropriate.
Research/creative work shall be evaluated which
(a) concerns topics, ideas, theories, or methods used in the teaching program of the Member's Department, or, where there is no department, comparable administrative unit;
(b) directly relates matters arising from (a) above to topics, ideas, theories, or methods of other areas in interdisciplinary fashion;
(c) topics, ideas, theories, or methods of other areas or disciplines that represent an evolution or development from (a) or (b).
Beyond Article 12.02.2.B.I, 12.02.2.B.II, and 12.02.2.B.III the onus shall lie with the Member to demonstrate that his/her work should be evaluated.
Factors that may be considered in the evaluation of research and creative activity include, but are not limited to, the publication of books, monographs, and contributions to edited books; papers in both refereed and non-refereed journals; papers delivered at professional meetings; grant writing; consulting work and other professional activities involving research competence; participation in panels; unpublished research including current work in progress; editorial and refereeing duties; creative works and performances; scholarship as evidenced by the Member's depth and breadth of knowledge and general contributions to the research life of the University.
Service to the University and Society
Where appropriate to the position, recognition shall be given to the contribution of the Member to the intellectual life and academic climate of the University through seminars, recitals, discussions, readings and debates; to the effectiveness of contributions to the functioning of the University through activities and work on University, Faculty, Department, and Association committees; to administrative activities related to the research and teaching functions of the University through duties as Department Chair or through other administrative assignments. General contributions to society shall include public lectures and participation in professional, academic, or governmental activities and organizations, and those community organizations related to the Member's University appointment.

Within the limitations set by the provisions of this Article, Faculty Councils may develop supplementary policies, subject to the approval of the General Faculties Council, relating to the criteria in Article 12.02.
Supplemental policies as described in Article 12.03.1 shall be publicly available and made known to all Members affected.
Supplemental policies as described in Article 12.03.1 may elaborate upon but are secondary to this Collective Agreement and may neither restrict nor prescribe outside the criteria in Article 12.02.
The criteria shall be weighted according to the duties assigned pursuant to Article 13; weightings are subject to Articles 13.03, and Schedule .
Personal or social compatibility shall not be a criterion for extension of probation, tenure, promotion, or salary increments.

item.hi: Guidelines Extension of Probation, Tenure, Promotion and Salary Increments

list.item: To qualify for the award of tenure, a Faculty Member shall have established the effectiveness of his/her teaching and a reasonable expectation of his/her ability to create a lengthy and meritorious record of effective teaching.

In addition, depending upon the disciplinary area to which the Faculty Member belongs, he/she shall be expected to show evidence of the development of an independent and productive program of research, scholarship and creative activity leading to a reasonable expectation of his/her ability to demonstrate some combination of maturity of scholarship and professional achievement.

item.hi: Award of Tenure at a Rank other than Assistant Professor

list.item: The application of the criteria for the award of tenure at a particular rank and salary shall be consistent with the application provided in Articles 12.05.1, 12.05.3and 12.05.5
To qualify for promotion to the rank of Associate Professor, a Faculty Member shall have established the effectiveness of his/her teaching over a period of years.

In addition, depending upon the disciplinary area to which the Faculty Member belongs, he/she shall be expected to show evidence of some combination of maturity of scholarship and professional achievement.
Promotion to the rank of Professor shall be based upon both a lengthy and meritorious record of effective teaching and significant scholarly or creative contributions to Faculty Member’s field.

Letters of reference from external referees shall be required. Salary Tenure Promotion Committees shall scrutinize recommendations for promotion to Professor with extreme care to ensure that the requirements have been met.

Apart from adjustments in salary that are proportionate to salary schedule changes, a Faculty Member can anticipate cumulative annual adjustments of salary through the award of increments. The awarding of increments reflects a well-established academic tradition whereby:
normal career progress which is demonstrated in continuing satisfactory professional performance, and
especially meritorious professional achievements are recognized through monetary reward.

Since the criteria which determine the award of increments are those which apply to promotion, there will be a degree of correspondence between salary and rank. Thus, on promotion or appointment, a Faculty Member will receive a salary which is not less than the minimum for the rank. However, at other times, the characteristics of a Faculty Member's professional performance may be reflected in the award of increments but not in promotion.
A decision by a personnel committee that a Faculty Member not be promoted shall not, in itself, imply that the Faculty Member's performance has been assessed to be unsatisfactory.
Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.

For the purposes of this Article, "consult" and "consultation" shall be taken to mean the opportunity to share information, provide input, and suggest alternatives, and seek advice and/or representation from the Association, before a final decision is made by the Dean/University Librarian.

The duties of a Member shall be deemed to have been assigned to the Member by the Dean/University Librarian according to the following guidelines:
Course assignments pursuant to Article 13.04.1shall be assigned by the Dean/University Librarian.
All other teaching, research, creative activity, and service duties in this Article shall be deemed to have been assigned by the Dean/University Librarian in consultation with the Member, as appropriate to the nature of the duty and consistent with Article 13.02.
Research and creative activities are not normally specifically assigned by the Dean/University Librarian; there are, however, clear expectations for Faculty Members/Professional Librarians as set out in Article 12.02and elaborated in Articles 11.05and 14.07.1.B.
Service duties to the University and community are not normally assigned to the Faculty Member/Professional Librarian/Instructor/Academic Assistant by the Dean/University Librarian; it is, however, a clear expectation for Faculty Members/Professional Librarian and, where included in the contract, Instructors and Academic Assistants, as set out in Articles 11.05, 12.02, and 15.08.1. A Member from whom service is expected may fulfil this requirement by appointment, designation, delegation, election, professional discretion, or re-assignment.

A Member may engage in external professional activity. External professional activity represents a contribution to the community which can be made by the Member by virtue of his/her training, advanced study or research, or is of value to maintain or develop his/her academic competence.

A Member shall notify the Dean/University Librarian of the nature and scope of any such activity of a substantial and continuing nature, with copies to the Association. The Dean/University Librarian shall ensure that such activity does not interfere with the normal activities of the Member.

A Member shall make appropriate arrangements in advance with the Dean/University Librarian for the use of facilities, equipment, supplies and other services of the University in the conduct of external professional work.

A Member shall obtain the approval of the Dean/University Librarian in advance before accepting remuneration for external professional activities, with copies to the Association. Such approval shall not unreasonably be withheld.
A Member shall not be required to report to their Dean/University Librarian receipt of remuneration of $1,000 or less per occurrence for professional activities including, but not limited to, delivery of guest lectures, serving as an external examiner, and conducting programme and manuscript reviews.
A Member shall report to their Dean/University Librarian when the annual total remuneration for the contract year (July 1 to June 30) exceeds $5,000 for external professional activities.
Before accepting remuneration from a research grant or contract, a Member must meet both of the following conditions:
The Vice-President (Academic) shall concur with the arrangements,
The supporting agency shall permit the use of funds to pay supplementary remuneration.

Each Faculty Member/Professional Librarian shall submit a Professional Activities Report to the Dean/University Librarian, in standardized form set forth in Schedule X, on or before September 15 of each year. Normally, the period covered shall be the contract year, that is, July 1 to June 30, immediately preceding the evaluation of performance.

Such reports shall be made available to personnel committees during consideration of the Faculty Member/Professional Librarian's probation, tenure, promotion or salary and for other uses that comply with the Collective Agreement.
Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.

Term appointments, probationary appointments, and term appointments with conversion shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Article 18.02, with copies of appointment letters provided to the Association. The Faculty Association shall also be notified of any subsequent changes to the terms of employment. Such notice shall be given in a timely manner and before the new terms of employment have been implemented. Academic staff Members shall be granted library privileges and an email account when their appointment letter is issued and shall retain these services for at least four months after their employment ends.
An initial appointment with tenure shall be subject to the provisions of Article 14.03respecting the award of tenure.

To deal with the appointment of a Professional Librarian, except as provided for in Article 14.02.2.B.II, there shall be a Search Committee, whose term of office shall be July 1 through June 30 annually, consisting of:
Non-Voting
The University Librarian as Chair
Voting
Four (4) persons selected through procedures established by the Professional Librarians Committee and approved by the General Faculties Council.

The procedures shall provide for a system of alternates. Alternates shall replace regular members whose schedules would cause unreasonable delay in a committee's proceedings or who would have a conflict of interest.
Quorum for a Search Committee shall consist of the University Librarian and three (3) of the four (4) voting members.
The affirmative vote of three (3) voting members shall be required to carry any recommendation placed before a Search Committee.

item.hi: Professional Librarians, Curriculum Laboratory of the Faculty of Education

list.item: To deal with the appointment of a Professional Librarian in the Curriculum Laboratory of the Faculty of Education, the procedure shall be jointly established by the Professional Librarians Committee and the Education Faculty Council and approved by the General Faculties Council. Any body established pursuant to the approved procedure shall serve a term of office from July 1 through June 30 annually.

item.hi: Appointment Procedure, Effective Date, and Relocation Allowance

list.item: The effective date of appointment, appointment procedure, and relocation allowance for Professional Librarians shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Article 18; except that in each case the University Librarian shall act in place of the Dean.

To deal with matters affecting the extension of probation, tenure, promotion and performance evaluation of a Professional Librarian, except as provided for in Article 14.02.2.B.II, there shall be a Salary Tenure Promotion Committee, whose term of office shall be July 1 through June 30 annually, consisting of:
Non-Voting
The University Librarian
Voting
Six (6) persons selected through procedures established by the Professional Librarians Committee and approved by the General Faculties Council.

The procedures shall provide for a system of alternates. Alternates shall replace regular members whose schedules would cause unreasonable delay of a committee's proceedings or whose membership could be seen as compromising procedural fairness.
Only tenured faculty and professional librarians may sit on a STP committee associated with this Article.
Quorum for a STP Committee shall consist of the full membership of the committee comprised of all voting and non-voting members.
The affirmative vote of four (4) members eligible to vote shall be required to carry any motion placed before a STP Committee.

In order to be eligible to vote in a particular case, voting members must be present at all meetings regarding that case. Notwithstanding the foregoing, an alternate joining a committee in place of a regular voting member part way through its deliberations on a particular case shall be eligible to vote provided that:
the Chair of the Committee has informed the alternate at the alternate's first meeting of the procedures followed and the nature of the committee's deliberations concerning the case prior to the alternate's membership in the committee, and
the alternate has attended all meetings of the committee concerning the case subsequent to the alternate's membership in the committee.
Procedures of a Salary Tenure Promotion Committee shall be subject to procedural fairness as defined in Article 2.22.
The Chair of a Salary Tenure Promotion Committee shall not be the University Librarian.

item.hi: Professional Librarians, Curriculum Laboratory of the Faculty of Education

list.item: To deal with matters affecting the extension of probation, tenure, promotion and performance evaluation of a Professional Librarian in the Curriculum Laboratory of the Faculty of Education, the procedures shall be jointly established by the Professional Librarians Committee and the Education Faculty Council and approved by the General Faculties Council.
Any body established pursuant to the approved procedure shall serve a term of office from July 1 through June 30 annually.
Probationary appointments shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Article 19.02.1.Aexcept that probationary appointments may be made at any rank.
Extension of probation shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Article 19.02.4except that the University Librarian shall act in place of the Dean.

Award of Tenure shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Article 19.03except that: in Article 19.03.4Librarian III and IV shall replace Associate Professor and Professor, respectively, and University Librarian shall replace Dean, and in Article 19.03.4.C.Icriteria in Article 14.07shall replace criteria in Article 12.
Procedure for extension of probation and award of tenure shall be as provided for faculty in Article 19.04.
Termination of Probationary Appointment shall be as provided for faculty in Article 19.05.

The classification of Professional Librarians by rank shall be, in ascending order:
Librarian II
Librarian III
Librarian IV

A Professional Librarian shall be promoted if recommended by the Library Salary Tenure Promotion Committee and recommended by the President and ratified by the Board, with copies provided to the Association.

A Professional Librarian may be considered for promotion at any time deemed appropriate in the judgement of the chair of the Library Salary Tenure Promotion Committee and with the consent of the Professional Librarian.
Normally, promotion from Librarian II to III, and from Librarian III to Librarian IV should occur after five (5) – ten (10) years in a rank.

A Professional Librarian shall have the right to be considered for promotion from Librarian II to Librarian III, and from Librarian III to Librarian IV during the interval from January 1 to March 31 of the sixth or subsequent year in which the librarian has been in a rank.
Librarians may not apply again to be promoted in the year following an unsuccessful consideration.

The procedure for the consideration of promotion of a Professional Librarian by the Library Salary Tenure Promotion Committee, and the effective date of promotion shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Articles 20.04, and 20.05, respectively, except the University Librarian shall replace the Dean.

Salary increments shall be as provided for Faculty Members in Article 21, except that the University Librarian shall act in place of the Dean, the Library shall be its own group for purposes of Articles 32, and the criteria shall be those of Article 14.07.
Appeals shall be as provided for faculty in Article 24.

item.hi: Criteria for Extension of Probation, Tenure, Promotion and Salary Increments

list.item:
The criteria for extension of probation, tenure, promotion and salary increments for Professional Librarians are:
Performance as a Professional Librarian
Effectiveness as a Professional Librarian is the primary criterion. Factors to be considered include the ability to perform consistently at an appropriate professional level in such areas as reference and information service, collection development, bibliography and cataloguing; instruction in library use and research methods; management of library personnel and operations; innovative development of library services, collections, and operations.
Research and Professional Development
Recognition is given to personally initiated research conducted over and above regularly assigned library service. Efforts shall be made to evaluate the quality and originality of both published and unpublished work and other work which has an impact upon the profession of librarianship, the provision of library services, or the dissemination of information and knowledge. Research and professional development which shall be considered for evaluation:
(a) concerns topics, ideas, theories, or methods used in the performance of professional activities;
(b) directly relates matters arising from (a) above to topics, ideas, theories, or methods of other areas in interdisciplinary fashion;
(c) topics, ideas, theories, or methods of other areas or disciplines that represent an evolution or development from (a) or (b).
Beyond Article 14.07.1.B.I.a, 14.07.1.B.I.b, and 14.07.1.B.I.c the onus shall lie with the Member to demonstrate that his/her work should be evaluated.
Beyond (i) and (ii) above, the onus shall lie with the Professional Librarian to demonstrate that his/her efforts should be evaluated.
Factors to be considered may include but are not limited to the innovative development of library service, collections, or operations which have an impact on the profession of librarianship; the publication of monographs and contributions to edited books; papers in refereed and non-refereed journals; papers delivered at professional meetings; participation in panels; consulting work and other professional activities involving research competence; unpublished research including current work in progress; editorial and refereeing duties; creative works and performances; and scholarship as evidenced by the candidate's advanced study and research in library and information science and/or a subject specialization, his/her depth and breadth of knowledge and general contributions to the research life of the University.
Service to the University and to Society
Factors to be considered include participation in University, Library, Faculty, Departmental and Association Committees; contributions to professional organizations; service on staff committees and task forces; administrative services other than that associated with the Member’s appointment; community service related to the Member’s University appointment.

Within the limitations set by the provisions of this Article, the Professional Librarians’ Committee may develop supplementary policies, subject to the approval of the General Faculties Council, relating to the criteria in Article 14.07.
Supplemental policies shall be publicly available and made known to all Members affected.
Supplemental policies may elaborate upon but are secondary to this Collective Agreement and may neither restrict nor prescribe outside the criteria in Article 14.07.
The criteria shall be weighted according to the duties assigned pursuant to Article 13; weightings are subject to Articles 13.04, 13.05.2, and Schedule .
Personal or social compatibility shall not be a criterion for extension of probation, tenure, promotion, or salary increments.

To qualify for appointment to the rank of Librarian II, the candidate shall have the minimum of a recognized professional degree in Library Science (M.L.S. or equivalent). In addition, there shall be the achievement of, or a reasonable expectation of, the development of a record of successful performance as a Professional Librarian, with a demonstration of a mastery of the skills and techniques of Librarianship as evidenced by effectiveness of professional performance; and evidence of the ability to develop and extend professional, disciplinary, and management expertise.

In addition, the candidate should show some evidence, or the expectation, of research and professional development in one or more of the following areas:
Academic achievement and activities, including additional formal study in Library Science and/or other relevant academic disciplines, programs in continuing education, research, and publication.
Involvement in professional activities and participation in professional organizations including service on committees, the presentation of papers, the organization of and participation in conferences, seminars, and workshops.
Contributions to the Library, the University, or the community.

The primary criterion for appointment or promotion to the rank of Librarian III shall be professional performance; the successful candidate shall have a record over a period of years, of significant achievement in librarianship, exercising sound independent judgment and creativity. There should be clear evidence of continuing professional development and demonstrated ability in an area of Library service and/or in an administrative capacity.

The candidate must also demonstrate achievement in research and professional development in one or more of the following areas:
Academic achievement and activities, including additional formal study in Library Science or other relevant academic disciplines, programs in continuing education; research, and publication.
Involvement in professional activities and participation in professional organizations including service on committees, the presentation of papers, organization of, and participation in conferences, seminars, workshops.
Contributions to the Library, the University, or the community.

For appointment or promotion to the rank of Librarian IV the successful applicant must have a record of outstanding professional accomplishment with demonstrated initiative, leadership and creativity. There should be evidence of further development and extension of professional expertise reflected by superior achievements and leadership in the field of service or specialization recognized beyond the University. Letters of reference from external referees shall be required.

In addition the candidate must submit evidence of substantial achievement in at least two of the following areas: research, publishing, professional endeavors including significant involvement in professional organizations; and in general contributions to the profession, the University, and society.
Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.
The primary duty of an Instructor is instruction.

A position description shall be developed by the Faculty or Department, as appropriate, and with the approval of the Dean/University Librarian, in consultation with the Instructor. The position description shall form part of the initial offer of appointment, with copies to the Association. The position description may be subject to alteration with the approval of the Dean/University Librarian in consultation with the Instructor as represented by the Association, with copies to the Association.

There are three ranks within the Instructor category:
Instructor I
The minimum qualification for appointment as Instructor I is a Bachelor’s Degree in the subject of interest, with appropriate experience.
Instructor II
The minimum qualification for appointment as Instructor II is a Bachelor’s Degree in the subject of interest, with appropriate experience, and a record of teaching effectiveness over a period of years. A Master’s Level degree in the subject of interest is desirable.
Instructor III
The minimum qualification for appointment as Instructor III is a Bachelor’s Degree in the subject of interest, with appropriate experience or appropriate professional qualifications, and a lengthy and meritorious record of teaching effectiveness. A doctoral degree in the subject of interest is desirable.
The Board shall establish and authorize the filling of each Instructor position.

Except when time does not permit, probationary and continuing Instructor positions shall be advertised within the University, on the "CAUT Bulletin", or in other appropriate media, with copies to the Association.

Applications for Instructor positions shall be considered by a Search Committee established under the provisions of Article 17which shall recommend to the Dean/University Librarian a candidate or candidates for the position. Candidates shall be offered the opportunity to meet with the Association prior to the receipt of a written offer of appointment.

If the Dean/University Librarian approves a recommended candidate, he/she shall send the candidate a written offer of appointment, provisional upon ratification by the Board, specifying the effective date, salary, duties and other conditions. This letter shall be copied to the Association. If the Dean/University Librarian rejects the recommendation of the Search Committee, his/her reasons shall be given to the President and to the Committee Chair with a copy to the Association, and he/she shall request the Search Committee to recommend another candidate or candidates.

In the event that a provisional offer of appointment is accepted, the Dean/University Librarian shall recommend the appointment of that candidate to the President, who shall report the Dean’s/University Librarian's recommendation to the Board.

If the Board ratifies a recommendation for appointment by the President, the President shall send an official letter of appointment to the candidate specifying the terms and conditions of the appointment.

The letter of appointment, countersigned by the appointee, and the Collective Agreement together constitute an agreement of appointment between the appointee and the University, with copies to the Association. Amendments to the Collective Agreement shall become part of such agreement of appointment.

Instructors will normally be appointed at the rank of Instructor I. A Dean/University Librarian may recommend to the Board appointment at the rank of Instructor II or Instructor III depending upon the needs of the Faculty and/or the qualifications/experience of the appointee.
Relocation Allowance: Refer to Schedule .
Instructors have certain duties and responsibilities which derive from their positions as teachers.

Instructors are not expected to conduct research or scholarship, other than that directly related to their teaching or position description duties. However, research activity which does not prevent Instructors from fulfilling their assigned responsibilities shall be allowed when approved in writing in advance by the Dean/University Librarian in consultation with the Department Chair where Departments exist, with copies to the Association.

Instructors have the right and responsibility to ensure their professional development as effective teachers. They have an obligation to develop and maintain competence and effectiveness within their area of expertise, to conscientiously prepare and organize their subject and to revise that subject matter on a regular basis as appropriate for that subject.

Instructors have the responsibility to act fairly toward all members of the University community, to foster a free exchange of ideas, and to respect the principles of confidentiality in a manner consistent with their instructional role.
Instructors shall have the right, and are encouraged, to attend and take part as members in Department/Faculty meetings and to vote in such bodies.
Consistent with their assigned duties, Instructors have the right, and are encouraged, to participate in the work of academic and professional associations.
An Instructor may request consideration for promotion after five (5) years in a rank, or in any year with the agreement of the Chair of the Salary, Tenure, and Promotion Committee.

Promotion in rank for Instructors follows a number of years of successful performance at the lower rank and requires a proven ability to successfully perform the duties appropriate to the next highest rank. Increased relevant qualifications, increased scope of practice and relevant expertise shall also be considered. Consistent with Article 15.02.4.D, maintaining relevant competence in the area of expertise is not sufficient in itself to merit promotion.
Promotion requires a positive recommendation of the relevant STP Committee, recommendation by the President, and ratification by the Board, with copies to the Association.

The procedure for the hearing of the STP Committee regarding the award of promotion shall be that for a hearing regarding promotion of a Faculty Member, as provided in Article 20.04. The motion to be considered by the STP Committee shall be:
That the quality and quantity of the candidate’s work relative to Article 15.02.4.Bmerit the award of promotion as an Instructor under Article 15.02.4.C.

The duties of an Academic Assistant will be according to a position description and will be primarily other than instruction in Department/Faculty course offerings. Such positions shall support the teaching and/or research functions of the University.

A position description shall be developed by the Faculty or Department, as appropriate, and with the approval of the Dean/University Librarian, in consultation with the Academic Assistant. The position description shall form part of the initial offer of appointment, with copies to the Association. The position description may be subject to alteration with the approval of the Dean/University Librarian in consultation with the Academic Assistant as represented by the Association, with copies to the Association.

There are three ranks within the Academic Assistant category:
Academic Assistant I, where a Bachelor's Degree in the subject of interest or an equivalent academic qualification shall be the minimum qualification.
Academic Assistant II, where a Master's Degree or equivalent in the subject of interest or a lesser academic qualification plus appropriate experience is required.
Academic Assistant III, where a doctoral degree or equivalent in the subject of interest, or a Master’s Degree and appropriate professional qualifications, or a lesser academic qualification plus appropriate experience and/or professional qualification is required.
The Board shall establish and authorize the filling of each Academic Assistant position.

Applications for Academic Assistant positions shall be considered by a Search Committee established under the provisions of Article 17which shall recommend to the Dean/University Librarian a candidate or candidates for the position. Candidates shall be offered the opportunity to meet with the Association prior to the receipt of a written offer of appointment.

If the Dean/University Librarian approves a recommended candidate, he/she shall send the candidate a written offer of appointment, provisional upon ratification by the Board, specifying the effective date, salary, duties and other conditions. If the Dean/University Librarian rejects the recommendation of the Search Committee, his/her reasons shall be given to the President and to the committee Chair, and he/she shall request the Search Committee to recommend another candidate or candidates.

In the event that a provisional offer of appointment is accepted, the Dean/University Librarian shall recommend the appointment of that candidate to the President, who shall report the Dean's/University Librarian's recommendation to the Board.

If the Board ratifies a recommendation for appointment by the President, the President shall send an official letter of appointment to the candidate specifying the terms and conditions of the appointment.

The letter of appointment, countersigned by the appointee, and the Collective Agreement together constitute an agreement of appointment between the appointee and the University, with copies to the Association. Amendments to the Collective Agreement shall become part of such agreement of appointment.
Relocation Allowance: Refer to Schedule .

The professional obligations and responsibilities of Academic Assistants, whose prime responsibilities are other than instruction in Department/Faculty course offerings shall consist of those duties and responsibilities described in their position descriptions.
In addition, and where applicable, the rights and responsibilities listed in Articles 15.02.4.C, 15.02.4.D, 15.02.4.E, 15.02.4.F, and 15.02.4.Gshall apply.
An Academic Assistant may request consideration for promotion after five (5) years in a rank, or in any year with the agreement of the Chair of the Salary, Tenure, and Promotion Committee.

In order for a promotion to be considered by the STP Committee, the Chair of the relevant Department (or equivalent) and the Dean/University Librarian shall agree that this recommendation may be considered based upon the availability of a continuing assignment appropriate to the higher rank. Such agreement shall not be unreasonably withheld.

Promotion in rank for Academic Assistants follows a number of years of successful performance at the lower rank and requires a proven ability to successfully perform the duties appropriate to the next highest rank. Increased relevant qualifications, increased scope of practice and relevant expertise shall also be considered.
