Upon receipt of the recommendation of the Dean/University Librarian the Vice-President (Academic) will either approve or deny the proposed gradual retirement plan. The decision of the Vice-President (Academic) shall be subject to Article 22.

The duration of the approved gradual retirement plan may be shortened with sufficient, written notice from the Member and subject to approval by the Dean/University Librarian, with copies to the Association. Such approval shall not unreasonably be withheld.
Reduced-load status is available to Members who hold, or are about to hold, a probationary appointment, appointment with tenure or a continuing appointment.
Reduced-load status shall continue to retirement unless it is terminated earlier by the mutual agreement of the Dean/University Librarian and the Member, with copies to the Association.

Reduced-load status applies to those with:
a full-load commitment for less than twelve (12) months but not less than six (6) months of the academic year, and to include at least one (1) of the four (4) month periods September 1 - December 31 or January 1 - April 30; or
a commitment less than full-load, but not less than fifty percent (50%) of the full-load equivalent on a twelve (12) month per year basis.

For each reduced-load status appointment, the proportion of the full-load equivalent and the period(s) of the year the Member's services are to be rendered, shall be set out in writing, invoking this Article, and agreed to by the Member and the Dean/University Librarian concerned, and approved by the Vice-President (Academic), with copies to the Association. The Member retains his/her right to Association representation as per 11.04.2. Reduced-load status will be granted only if satisfactory arrangements for teaching, student supervision and other responsibilities can be made.

Subject to the above conditions and by mutual agreement of the Member and the Dean/University Librarian, changes to the proportion of the full-load equivalent and the period(s) of the year the Member’s services are to be rendered may be set out in writing and approved by the Vice-President (Academic), with copies to the Association

item.hi: Salary for Gradual Retirement & Reduced Load Status

list.item: The actual salary paid to a Member on gradual retirement shall be proportional, as determined by the duties and responsibilities agreed to in the approved gradual retirement plan, to the nominal salary. The nominal salary shall be that which would be paid to the member were he/she employed on a full-load basis.

The actual salary paid to a Member on reduced-load status shall be proportional, as determined by the duties and responsibilities specified in the reduced-load status agreement, to the nominal salary. The nominal salary shall be that which would be paid to the Member were he/she employed on a full-load basis.

item.hi: Increments for Members on Gradual Retirement or on Reduced Load Status

list.item: Increments are to be awarded in accordance with Article 21.

For a Member on gradual retirement, the actual value of the increment shall be proportional, as determined by the duties and responsibilities agreed to in the approved gradual retirement plan, to the size of the salary increment as determined in Article 21.05.12. The Dean shall inform the Member in writing of the actual value of the increment, with copies to the Association.

For a Member on reduced load status, the actual value of the increment shall be proportional, as determined by the duties and responsibilities specified in the reduced-load status agreement, to the size of the salary increment as determined in Article 21.05.12. The Dean shall inform the Member in writing of the actual value of the increment, with copies to the Association.

item.hi: Economic Benefits for Members on Gradual Retirement or on Reduced-Load Status

list.item: The terms and conditions for pension coverage shall be subject to the regulations of the Universities Academic Pension Plan.
If the reduction from full-load is less than or equal to twenty percent (20%), the Member and the University continue to remit their respective pension contributions based on the full-load salary.

If the reduction from full-load is more than twenty percent (20%), the Member may opt to purchase the full-load pension contribution entitlement by paying both the Board's and the Member's pension contribution shares on the reduced portion. The Board and Member continue to pay their respective pension contribution shares for the portion as determined by the duties and responsibilities agreed to in the approved gradual retirement plan

Benefits shall be as in Schedule , except that:
The Professional Supplement and Relocation Allowance shall be proportional to that determined by the duties and responsibilities agreed to in the approved gradual retirement plan or reduced-load status agreement.
The actual salary as established in Article 33.05shall govern the level of long-term disability insurance coverage.
Copies of all agreements, contracts, and letters required by this article shall be copied to the Association at the same time as they are sent to the Member.

There are two types of leave: Voluntary and Involuntary.
Voluntary leaves are those requested by the member in order to pursue professional development, political or other forms of community engagement, and similar opportunities.
Involuntary leaves are those requested by or granted to the member in response to personal, family, medical, or other types of situations that require the absence of a member from their duties.
Voluntary and involuntary leaves may be paid or unpaid depending on the circumstances.

item.hi: Impact of Leave on Career Progress, Salary, and Seniority

list.item: Time spent on paid leave, including leave in which the Member receives contributions from a Supplemental Unemployment Benefit (SUB) Plan, counts as continuous service for the purposes of Seniority in Article 26 (Termination of Appointment for Financial Emergency or Due to Program Redundancy). See also Article 26.08.3.
Unpaid leave does not count as continuous service for the purposes of Article 26 (Termination of Appointment for Financial Emergency or Due to Program Redundancy). See also Article 26.08.3.

For the purposes of Article 21.05.12 (Increments), Members on leave (paid or unpaid) are deemed to have achieved satisfactory performance and normal career progress as defined in Article 21.05.4 provided their score under Article 21.05 in the evaluation period immediately preceding their leave was 1.0 or higher Article 34.03.1.a.
Members whose previous evaluation under Article 21.05 was less than 1.0 shall be deemed to have received the same score as their previous evaluation, unless the Dean has evidence of improved performance.
Members who have not received an evaluation under under Article 21.05 prior to going on leave shall be deemed to have achieved satisfactory performance and normal career progress.
Time spent on leave (whether paid or unpaid) does not count as service for the purposes of calculating Academic Career Years, or time to Probation, Promotion, or Tenure.
During any period of leave, Members shall retain their rank and tenure (if applicable).

Requests for Voluntary Leaves shall be made in writing by members to their deans.
The dean, in consultation with the department chair in faculties where there are departments, shall evaluate the request and make a recommendation to the Provost.
Requests for voluntary leave shall not be denied unreasonably.

In all cases where a request for Voluntary Leave is denied, the Provost shall provide a letter to the Member detailing the specific rationale for this denial. A copy of this letter shall be sent to the Faculty Association.

Upon written request to the Dean, the University shall grant to an academic staff member leave of absence without pay to seek nomination as a candidate, to be a candidate, and to hold elected political office in municipal, provincial, or federal government.

The academic staff member shall inform the Dean when deciding to seek candidacy, and shall make every attempt to give the longest possible notice and shall actively cooperate in arrangements for the uninterrupted continuation of the work of the academic unit.
The leave may be partial or complete depending upon the requirements of the academic staff member's responsibilities. The leave shall be for a specific term and may be renewed.

At the expiration of the leave the academic staff member may return to employment with the University and shall be granted rights and privileges associated with employment with the University, with service (including for the calculation of career years) counting up to the date the leave commenced and resuming after the leave is concluded. In the case of partial leave, service time shall be prorated.
During the period of leave, Members shall retain their rank and tenure and shall be entitled to such benefits as are available.

A leave of absence without pay to provide professional assistance on a full-time basis to an outside agency or pursuant to an arrangement for faculty exchange may be granted to a Member when the following conditions are met:
The Member's primary duties can be covered by a replacement deemed to be satisfactory by the University.
The Board's obligations in this section do not extend beyond one (1) year's leave in five (5) years of paid full-time service at the University. Nothing in this section shall preclude further leaves of absence being taken by mutual agreement between the Member and the Board.
Upon the granting of leave, the Board shall specify the extent of the Member's duties, if any, to the University during the period of leave.
Secondments may also be proposed by the Board with the approval of the Member in question.
An academic staff member with the exception of those holding Sessional or Term appointments may be granted a leave of absence for the purpose of pursuing academic studies.

Application must be made in writing to the Dean/University Librarian eight (8) months before the commencement of the leave. The Dean/University Librarian shall respond at least five (5) months before the commencement of the leave.
Education leave is normally for a maximum period of up to two (2) years per request. An application may be made for renewal for a maximum of one additional year.
The University shall award a grant of 100% of the academic staff member's salary for the first year (or longer if mutually agreed) to assist with the costs associated with educational advancement.

The recipient of an education leave grant must agree to return to duties at the University for a period equal to that for which the grant was received, or to reimburse the University for the full amount of the grant received.
If a member returns to the University for a period of time less than the length of the leave, the reimbursement shall be prorated accordingly.
Any of the above specifications may be waived by mutual agreement between the Dean, the academic staff member, and the Faculty Association.
An academic staff member may be granted leave of absence with or without pay for good and sufficient reason. Such leaves shall not be withheld unreasonably.

Whether the leave is proposed with or without pay. When the proposal is for a leave with pay, the application shall include a rationale for the continuation of pay.

Applications shall be submitted normally no later than the semester before the proposed start date. Exceptions may be granted in the case of emergent opportunities.

item.hi: Recognition of the unique nature of involuntary leave

list.item: The Board and the Association acknowledge that involuntary leaves frequently involve emergent situations and often occur at times of great stress in members' lives and those of their families.

The Board and Association recognise that members' first duty in such cases is towards the preservation of life and limb, the satisfaction of legal requirements, and ensuring the health and safety of others.
Whenever these duties interfere with reporting requirements, notification requirements, and/or timelines in this Article, this first duty shall take precedence.
Waivers, exceptions, and retroactive reporting shall be provided whenever required by this recognition.
Members can ask the Association to act on their behalf.
In every case where an application for involuntary leave or disability is denied, notice shall be given in writing to the President, the Association and the Member.
In all cases on involuntary leave, appeals shall be to a joint committee consisting of the President of the University and President of the Association.

“Medical leave” includes leave for sickness, injury, short term disability, consultation with health care professionals and stays in hospitals or other institutions for prescribed medical care when such event prevents the staff member from performing the duties the staff member was performing immediately prior to the commencement of the sickness or injury; and
“Medical certificate” means a certificate verifying the medical condition in accordance with relevant legislation signed by a qualified physician.

Medical Leaves of up to twenty (20) working days are a departmental matter. Members shall inform their Department Chair or immediate supervisor before the leave begins (in the case of preplaned medical procedures) or as soon as practical after its commencement and provide an estimate of its duration.
The Chair shall inform the dean in cases where the estimated duration shall be longer than ten (10) working days.
The Dean may require the Member to arrange for a medical certificate to be sent to the Wellness Office in cases where a leave exceeds five (5) working days.

If the Member has been on medical leave and absent from duties for more than twenty (20) working days or if the member expects the medical leave to result in an absence of more than twenty (20) working days, a medical certificate shall be filed with the Wellness Officer.
The Wellness officer shall confirm receipt of the medical certificate in writing to the Dean and Provost with a copy of the letter to the Association.

The Provost shall then inform the member in writing that he or she is on medical leave.
This letter will indicate the date on which the leave began (or in cases where advance notice has been given, shall begin).
A copy of this letter shall be sent to the Faculty Association.
In no case shall the start date of a medical leave be earlier than the first day of reported or predicted absence.
During medical leave, a member shall remain on full pay and benefits.

A member may remain on medical leave for one hundred and thirty (130) working days in aggregate for each sickness or injury within a three hundred and sixty-five (365) day period, counting from the first day of actual absence.

A new medical leave and a new three hundred and sixty-five (365) day period is deemed to have begun whenever there has been a minimum of sixty-five (65) working days of service following a previously authorized leave for the same illness or injury.

If the medical leave exceeds 130 working days, the Member shall apply for disability benefits, pursuant to Article AE.
If the application is approved, the member shall be placed on disability leave.
If the application is not approved, the member shall apply for "Other Involuntary leave" under Article 34.05.9, return to duties, or transition to retirement under Article 33.

If there is any doubt about the medical capability of the member to perform the regular university responsibilities, the member or the Dean may recommend in writing to the Provost that the member be evaluated by a qualifed physician. A copy of this letter shall be sent to the Association.
After consultation with the Association, the Provost may require that the staff member be examined by a physician who is acceptable to the Association and the Provost.
A member who does not wish to submit to an examination by this physician may either withdraw their application or propose an alternate who is acceptable to the Provost and Association.
If an examination is held under this Article, the member shall authorise the examining physician to provide a medical certificate indicating whether medical leave is required and the estimated length.
A refusal to undergo examination or authorise this release shall be considered a withdrawal of the member's application.

The examining physician shall report to the Wellness Officer whether the member is medically capable of performing their responsibilities and, if not, an estimate of whether and when the member would be able to assume those responsibilities in the future.
The Wellness Officer shall review the physician's report and pass on the physician's estimation about the members current or future ability to carry out their duties to Provost.
A copy of this letter, which must not contain protected medical information, shall be sent to the member and the Association.
In the event the Member or the Association disagrees wth the assessment as summarised by the Wellness Officer, they may arrange for an external evaluation which also shall be provided to the Provost.
In each case, the Provost shall endeavour to reach a negotiated resolution with the member.

item.hi: Leave upon the birth or adoption of a child

list.item: A Member holding a tenure-track, tenured, or term appointment shall be granted maternity, adoption, or parental leave for a combined period of up to eighteen (18) months by the Dean after having been employed by the University for more than thirteen (13) consecutive weeks. The first thirty-seven (37) weeks of leave is compensated by the University. Thereafter leave is unpaid.
Any pregnant member who has been employed for at least 90 days by the University is entitled to unpaid maternity leave.
A pregnant member who qualifies under Article 34.05.4.A shall be entitled to a maximum of thirty-seven (37) weeks compensated maternity and parental leave per pregnancy.
Any member who has been employed for at least 90 days by the University is entitled to unpaid adoption leave.
A member who qualifies under Article 34.05.4.A shall be entitled to a maximum of thirty-seven (37) weeks compensated primary adoption leave per adoption.

Primary adoption leave may be claimed by only one Member per adoption.
When two Members share responsibility for a single adopted child, only one Member may identify as the primary adoption parent; the other member is entitled to Parental Leave only.

Members who have not accessed Maternity or Primary Adoption Leave are entitled to a maximum of thirty-seven (37) weeks parental leave per pregnancy or adoption.
All members who have worked for the University for a minimum of 90 days are eligible for unpaid leave.
Members who qualify under Article 34.05.4.A are entitled to compensated leave.

For the first two weeks of Maternity Leave, Primary Adoption Leave, or Parental Leave, the University shall pay a Member who qualifies under Article 34.05.4.A one hundred percent (100%) of the salary they were earning immediately before the beginning of the leave period.
Thereafter, the University shall pay the difference between the Federal Employment Insurance Benefit and the member's salary at the beginning of the leave period.
The maximum period for payment under this arrangement is thirty-seven (37) weeks.
All benefit coverage shall remain in effect and normal employer/employee deductions shall apply throughout the period.
An academic staff member shall be granted additional leave without pay beyond the initial thirty-seven (37) weeks for the balance of the eighteen month period.

The academic staff member shall give the University at least four (4) weeks’ written notice of the date the leave is to begin. The notice period may be waived by mutual agreement between the member and the University.

Upon return to work, an academic staff member who has taken leave under this Article shall resume the member’s former position with full salary and benefits as provided under this collective agreement.
Academic staff members shall be granted compassionate care leave of up to eight (8) weeks when an event such as illness, injury, or death in a member’s immediate family occurs.

The academic staff member shall inform the Dean in writing stating the reason the leave is required. The member shall be entitled to receive one hundred (100) per cent of salary for the first two weeks of compassionate care leave. Thereafter leave will be without pay.
Leaves for longer periods without pay may be granted by the Dean. The member may be eligible for Federal Employment Insurance Compassionate Care Benefits throughout this period.
For the purposes of this Article, "Immediate family" means: parents, siblings, spouse or common-law partner, children, or grandchildren.
Domestic violence does not have to involve sexual threats or activity.
The Board will develop and implement a domestic violence policy in accordance with this Article.

The Board and the Association will protect the confidentiality of a member who accesses the domestic violence policy. Information will be disclosed only as necessary to meet the objectives of the policy, or when there is serious or imminent risk to the safety of the faculty member or other members of the University community.
No member shall be subject to retaliation or disciplinary action for accessing this policy or for absences related to domestic violence.
Access to domestic violence leave shall not be unreasonably denied.

An academic staff member who is called for jury duty or who is subpoenaed by any body in Canada with the power to do so (other than when the member is the plaintiff), shall be granted leave of absence with pay.
The member shall inform the Dean as soon as possible after receiving notification of being required to appear in court, and may be required to present proof of such notification.
The member shall remit to the University all compensation received from the court, other than amounts received for travelling or living expenses.
When an academic staff member wishes time off in order to pursue a civil action unrelated to his or her duties in court, the member shall apply to the Dean for leave of absence without pay.
Members of the Academic Staff who face civil litigation for work associated with their duties may apply for a paid leave of absence.

An academic staff member may be granted leave of absence with pay by the Dean for up to ten working days for personal circumstances such as birth or adoption in the family, grave illness or bereavement in the family, or to attend to urgent personal matters which cannot otherwise be accomplished.
In an emergency, an application may be made by telephone (to be confirmed in writing) to the Dean or via the Association where the particular circumstances warrant it.
Leaves for longer periods, with or without pay, may be granted by the Dean.
An academic staff member may be granted leave of absence with or without pay for good and sufficient reason. Such leaves shall not be withheld unreasonably.

The proposed start and end dates of the leave

When ever reasonably practicable the Board shall use continuing appointments to meet the continuing staffing needs of the University. However when one or more conditions under 35.03exist, the Dean/University Librarian may recommend the appointment of a Sessional Lecturer.
The recommendation to make a Sessional Appointment shall be in writing, with a copy to the Association, stating the reason(s) under 35.03for recommending this appointment.
Recommendations to make a Sessional Appointment under this article are Grievable under the provisions of Article 22
Sessional Lecturers may teach no more than one (1) semester course in a designated semester.
The maximum ratio of credit hours taught by Sessional Lecturers to those taught by faculty Members, Instructors, and Academic Assistants is 1:5.

Sessional ranks
Every appointment of a sessional lecturer shall be to one of the following ranks
Sessional Lecturer I
Sessional Lecturer II
Sessional Lecturer III
Sessional Lecturer IV
The rank of appointment shall be determined as follows:
Sessional Lecturer I: The Academic staff member possesses a Bachelor's degree or equivalent relevant professional experience
Sessional Lecturer II: the academic staff member possesses a Master's degree, or has taught 12 three hour courses or equivalent at the rank of Sessional Lecturer I (or equivalent at another institution)
Sessional Lecturer III: the academic staff member possess a PhD or equivalent, has taught 15 three credit courses at the rank of Sessional Lecturer II (or equivalent at another University), or has previously held an appointment as an Instructor, Librarian, or Faculty Member (or an equivalent at another institution).
Sessional Lecturer IV: the academic staff member has taught the 10 three credit courses at the rank of Sessional Lecturer III (or equivalent at another university) or has more than two years experience as a faculty member (at the University of Lethbridge or another institution).

The appointment of a Sessional Lecturer will take into account relevant experience as described in Article 35.09.3, academic qualifications and, where appropriate, prior teaching effectiveness as determined through previous performance evaluation(s).
The appointment of Sessional Lecturers must be approved by the Vice President (Academic) on behalf of the Board, with a copy to the Association.

In order to maintain an experienced academic staff, the University shall maintain a list of give preference in Sessional Appointments to individuals who have the requisite qualifications and have been members of the Academic Staff at any rank including Sessional Lecturer for at least three semesters in the previous three years.
This provision shall apply unless the member has been informed in writing by the Dean that their teaching performance as defined in Article AE$$Missing Reference$$(Faculty) or Article AE (Sessionals) has been unsatisfactory.
For the purposes of 35.09.3.A, the University shall maintain a list of all

In applying for courses, sessional lecturers may claim preference for a maximum of three vacancies in a single semester. If a course assigned on the basis of that preference is cancelled or assigned to another member, the member may claim preference of another course that has not already been assigned. In the event that the member is not appointed to any of their preferred courses, the member's seniority under Article will be extended by one semester.
Members shall retain their seniority for a maximum of two years following their last appointment at the university.

When more than one applicant for a sessional posting holds preferential status, the following criteria shall be used to determine priority
the person who is most qualified shall be appointed
if two or more candidates are equally qualified, a Sesslional Lecturer III shall be appointed in preference to a Sessional Lecturer II and a Sessional Lecturer II shall be appointed in preference to a Sessional Lecturer I.
if two or more candidates are equally qualified and at the same rank, the candidate who has taught the course the most in the previous five years shall be appointed.
if two or more candidates are equally qualified under the previous article, the dean shall make a random selection among the finalists.

The University, in conjunction with the Faculty Association, shall inform Deans, Directors, Department Heads, and academic staff members at the beginning of very semester concerning these preference provisions and the requirement that they be followed in sessional appointments.
The University shall maintain the Sessional Preference List and distribute a current copy no later than 30 days before the beginning of each semester.
A candidate who does not have preferential rights to an appointment may be appointed on an extraordinary basis over candidates with preferential rights as defined in the previous Article.

Such appointments are intended to allow the university to take advantage of extraordinary opportunities (such as the availability of an internationally recognised expert in a given field). They are not intended to be used on a regular basis.
In order to make such an appointment, the dean must provide a rationale for the extraordinary appointment in writing to the Provost, with a copy to the Faculty Association.

Members with preferential rights who are denied a course on the basis of an extraordinary appointment shall be informed of this in writing. Unless they receive a different appointment in that same semester, their seniority rights will be extended for an additional 12 months from the begining of the semester in which the extraordinary appointment is made.

If circumstances preclude posting in the normal fashion, the Faculty Association shall be informed before potential candidates are contacted. This notice shall contain the information specified in 35.09.5.A.Vand be provided to candidates as they are contacted.

Academic staff members shall be granted library privileges and an email account when their appointment letter is issued and shall retain these services for at least four months after their employment ends;

In the event that work such as that in Article is required prior to the signing of a Letter of Appointment or after the completion of a contract, compensation at the rate of 1/36 of the based stipend for the Sessional Lecturer's proposed rank shall be provided for each day or part thereof of proposed work. In no case shall less than one (1) day be negotiated per proposed task.
An offer of appointment normally shall be extended to the successful candidate no later than 45 days before the start of the semester.

Normally, a successful candidate shall be given at least 7 days to respond to the offer of appointment. This response shall be in writing.
If a response is required in less than seven (7) days, the successful candidate shall receive a sum equal to an additional 1/20 of the base stipend for his or her rank in lieu of this deliberation time.
The amount in Articles are cumulative where applicable.

In the event a course is cancelled by the university, Sessional lecturers who have accepted an appointment shall receive the following compensation
For a course cancelled between 30 and 14 days before the first day of classes, 1/10 of the stipend
For a course cancelled between 13 and 7 days before the first day of classes, 1/5 of the stipend
For a course canelled six days or less before the first day of classes, 1/4 of the stipend

item.hi: CODE OF CONDUCT BOARD OF GOVERNORS FACULTY REPRESENTATIVES
item.p: Two members of academic staff of the University of Lethbridge serve as members of the Board of Governors of the University of Lethbridge and thus serve the University in two very important ways.

Within the framework of the Post-Secondary Learning Act, the Board of Governors is charged with establishing and implementing strategy, policy and governance and with ensuring accountability to the people of Alberta. The members of academic staff deliver the core academic mandate of the University in teaching, research and scholarship, and service.

The Board of Governors and the University of Lethbridge Faculty Association recognize that it is possible for some ambiguity and potential conflict to occur as members of academic staff perform their service as academic staff and as governors. The following framework is intended to provide guidance in these situations to members of academic staff serving on the Board, other Board members, members of academic staff and administrators.

The Board of Governors and the University of Lethbridge Faculty Association agree that:
1. When they are acting in their capacity as members of academic staff all of the relevant provisions of the Collective Agreement apply to members of academic staff serving as Board members. That is, members of academic staff serving as Board members retain all of the rights and responsibilities of members of the academic staff including the provisions of academic freedom, the right to question and criticize the administration of the University, and the right to grieve violations of the Collective AGreement by the administration.
2. The governance documents of the Board are: “Charter of Expectations for the Board of Governors”, “Code of Conduct and Ethics for the Board of Governors”, “Terms of Reference for an Individual Governor”, and “Rules of Operation of the Board of Governors”. These governance documents shall apply at all times to members of academic staff serving as Board members.
3. Academic staff, like other members of the Board, are required to sign a “confidentiality agreement” and, to adhere to the confidentiality policy outlined in Article 3 in the Board “Code of Conduct”.
4. In any situation where ambiguity of roles may exist, in interactions between members of academic staff serving as Board members and Senior Academic Administrators, it is necessary for the Board member and the administrator to be clear whether the Board member is acting primarily as a member of the academic staff or as a governor. Where, after consultation with the Member, the administrator remains uncertain as to whether the Member is acting in his or her capacity as a Faculty Member or a member of the Board, the administrator may ask the Member to declare in writing and in a timely manner the capacity in which he or she is acting.
5. Should a member of academic staff who is a Board member grieve in his or her capacity as a member of academic staff an alleged violation by the administration of the Collective Agreement, that Member shall declare to the Board Chair his or her potential conflict of interest before the next meeting of the Board.

c) The Tenant shall keep the Day Care Centre open for business and in normal operation at least 10 hours per day, Monday to Friday inclusive, with the exception of holidays or holiday periods during which the University is closed.
2. Faculty Association Responsibilities:

2.1 The Faculty Association shall make a one-time payment of $20,000.00 towards the construction costs of the day care facility which shall be paid by the Faculty Association to the University on or before September 1, 2009.

2.2 The Faculty Association agrees that each member of the Faculty Association will contribute the sum of $1.80 per month for each month that the individual is a member of the Faculty Association commencing September 1, 2009 with such contributions to continue by Faculty Members for a period of 20 years following the date the day care opens for operation.

2.3 In the event that the day care facility is not in operation due to the absence of a day care provider prior to September 1, 2009, the individual monthly contributions by member s of the Faculty Association shall be suspended for the period during which the day care facility is not in operation commencing with the month immediately following the month in which the day care operation was suspended or discontinued with such contributions resuming with the month following the month in which the day care facility recommences operation.

2.4 The Faculty Association agrees that the monthly contributions shall be automatically deducted by the University from the remuneration paid to each Faculty Member and on behalf of each Faculty Member hereby authorizes the University to make such a deduction. In the event that an amendment to the collective agreement between the University and the Faculty Association agree to take such steps as may be required to give effect to these provisions, the University and the Faculty Association agree to take such steps as may be required to amend the collective agreement accordingly.

2.5 The faculty Association will provide annual input, by July of each year, to the Vice-President (Finance and Administration) in relation to the annual Landlord/Tenant review meetings on issues or recommendations related to the Day Care Centre.
3. This Agreement shall endure to the benefit of and be binding upon the Parties hereto and their respective successors and assigns.

item.hi: CONFLICT OF INTEREST AND/OR CONFLICT OF COMMITMENT DECLARATION
item.p: Further to agreement reached at bargaining in 2013, the parties agree that Members shall complete a web-based Employee Declaration Disclosure Form (attached) for the declaration of any conflict of interest and/or conflict of commitment. This disclosure is made when the Member's appointment commences and annually thereafter at the beginning of the calendar year. It replaces the paper declaration form previously submitted with the Members annual Professional Activities Report.

If at any time during the year, there is reasonable cause to believe that a current or anticipated conflict of interest or commitment may exist (11.05.5), the Member must disclose this to their Dean/University Librarian as soon as possible after the Member becomes aware of it, and record it through the web-based form. Notification of approval, if granted, will come through the web-based system from the Associate Vice-President (Human Resources & Administration) on behalf of the Dean/University Librarian.
Further information can be found within the Conflict of Interest and/or Commitment Policy.
